8 
[paragraph] 20 In very many of the Cryptocarpae/Carybosa, Oceania, (5.a&b) 
Polyxenia) there is a circular valvate, muscular 
membrane developed from the inner and under edge of 
the disc - In the Phanerocarpae such a membrane does not 
seem to be present but in Rhizostoma & Cephea it is evidently 
replaced by the inflexed edge of the disc (f 26a) <s>The [text?] 
[text?] appears to be the great agent in effecting the 
progression of the animal<\s> 
[paragraph] 21 <u>Of the Marginal Corpuscles<\u>.  In the <u>Cryptocarpae<\u> the marginal 
corpuscles are sessile upon the circular vessel (f. 8.9.10) They are 
spheroidal vesicles about   in diam. containing a clear fluid 
and one or more spherical strongly refracting bodies - in diam. 
and occasionally included within a delicate cell - the 
marginal vesicles are placed between the inner and outer membranes 
of the circular vessel - 
In the <u>Phanerocarpae<\u> (Phacellophora)  the marginal corpuscle 
(fig. 25.25a) is placed at the extremity of a short double walled tubular pedicle 
projecting downwards or towards the ventral surface of the disc 
the under margins of the fissure in which it is lodged are prolonged 
into two overlapping fringes - the cavity of the pedicle is 
continuous with that of a canal which runs from the common 
cavity directly towards the corpuscle - Its walls are continuous, 
the inner, with the inner wall of the canal - the outer with 
the substance of the disc - The pedicle is in fact a mere 
process of the system of canals so that the position of the marginal 
vesicle is relatively to this system the same as in the Cryptocarpae. 
A similar remark holds good with regard to the Rhizostomidae. 
[paragraph] 22. In Cephea and Rhizostoma the organ is placed  in a notch between 
two lobe like processes of the margin of the disc and looks upwards.
